title: Learn SQL with Step-by-Step Visual Execution
subtitle1: Master the fundamentals of SQL — from basics to advanced concepts.
subtitle2: Learn interactively, visualize data, and grow your real-world skills step by step.
cardcontent: Ananya works as a junior data analyst at EduTrack University. She’s been assigned to prepare a report card summary from the students table. But she noticed that some students are from the same department, and her mentor asked her to calculate average marks by department instead of listing every student. She remembered hearing about a magical SQL word — GROUP BY — that can help summarize data. Let’s see how Ananya learns to use it!
content2: Here are the tables we'll be working with:
codeComQuery:
-- 1️ View all student records 
 SELECT * 
 FROM students; 
 
-- 2️ Average marks by department 
 SELECT  
     department,  
     AVG(marks) AS average_marks 
 FROM students 
 GROUP BY department; 
 
-- 3️ Average marks by department, sorted by performance (highest first) 
 SELECT  
     department,  
     AVG(marks) AS average_marks 
 FROM students 
 GROUP BY department 
 ORDER BY average_marks DESC; 
 
-- 4️ Create a summary table with department averages 
 -- ⚠️ This will create a new table with the aggregated results 
 CREATE TABLE department_summary AS 
 SELECT  
     department,  
     AVG(marks) AS average_marks 
 FROM students 
 GROUP BY department;
card2content: Before giving the answer, the code will be examined slowly and clearly, covering every part in a structured sequence.

table2.title: Find Average Marks by Department
table2.word: Ananya wants to know how each department performs on average.  She uses GROUP BY with the AVG() function.
table2.code: SELECT department, AVG(marks) AS average_marks FROM students GROUP BY department;

table3.title: Sort the Results (to find top-performing  department)
table3.word: Now Ananya can clearly see which department is performing best!
table3.code: SELECT department, AVG(marks) AS average_marks FROM students GROUP BY department ORDER BY average_marks DESC;

table4.title: Create a Summary Table (Optional)
table4.word: This creates a new table with summarized department performance.
table4.code: CREATE TABLE department_summary AS SELECT department, AVG(marks) AS average_marks FROM students GROUP BY department;
